channel.title: Nature Articles - Quantum Simulation
channel.description: Recent articles from Nature, Nature Physics, and Nature Photonics on Quantum Simulation.

item.title: Strongly interacting Meissner phases in large bosonic flux ladders
item.description:
The quantum simulation of driven, strongly correlated phases at large scales is challenging, primarily due to detrimental heating effects. Now, a large-scale interacting Mott–Meissner phase has been realized in a neutral atom quantum simulator.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: P: 1-7
item.author: Alexander Impertro, SeungJung Huh, Monika Aidelsburger

item.title: Hamiltonian engineering of collective XYZ spin models in an optical cavity
item.description:
Spin models that can be emulated by quantum simulators are usually restricted to systems with conserved total magnetization. The tuning of photon-mediated interactions between atoms in a cavity enables the implementation of more general models also useful for quantum sensing tasks.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: P: 1-8
item.author: Chengyi Luo, Haoqing Zhang, James K. Thompson

item.title: Continuous recoil-driven lasing and cavity frequency pinning with laser-cooled atoms
item.description:
Experiments with cold atoms in optical cavities are often limited to discontinuous operation due to reloading requirements. Now, continuous lasing is demonstrated with strontium atoms in a ring cavity, stabilized by atom loss mechanisms.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: P: 1-7
item.author: Vera M. Schäfer, Zhijing Niu, James K. Thompson

item.title: Resourceful dissipation
item.description:
Controlled dissipation enables the extraction of equilibrium properties of ultracold one-dimensional gases through the observation of anomalous dynamics.
Type: News & Views Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 21, P: 497-498
item.author: Yann Kiefer

item.title: Simulating two-dimensional lattice gauge theories on a qudit quantum computer
item.description:
Qubit-based simulations of gauge theories are challenging as gauge fields require high-dimensional encoding. Now a quantum electrodynamics model has been demonstrated using trapped-ion qudits, which encode information in multiple states of ions.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 21, P: 570-576
item.author: Michael Meth, Jinglei Zhang, Martin Ringbauer

item.title: Deterministic remote entanglement using a chiral quantum interconnect
item.description:
Large quantum computers are likely to require methods of connecting devices by transmitting and absorbing photons. Entanglement between two superconducting qubit devices has now been established using a waveguide with tunable directionality.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: P: 1-6
item.author: Aziza Almanakly, Beatriz Yankelevich, William D. Oliver

item.title: Author Correction: Observation of Nagaoka polarons in a Fermi–Hubbard quantum simulator
item.description:
No Description
Type: Amendments and Corrections Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 639, P: E23
item.author: Martin Lebrat, Muqing Xu, Markus Greiner

item.title: Orbital hybridization in graphene-based artificial atoms
item.description:
Orbital hybridization in artificial atoms is achieved by altering their shape, and the anisotropy of the confining potential gives rise to the hybridization between quasibound states with different orbital quantum numbers within the artificial atom.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 639, P: 73-78
item.author: Yue Mao, Hui-Ying Ren, Qing-Feng Sun

item.title: Thermalization and criticality on an analogue–digital quantum simulator
item.description:
A hybrid analogue–digital quantum simulator is used to demonstrate beyond-classical performance in benchmarking experiments and to study thermalization phenomena in an XY quantum magnet, including the breakdown of Kibble–Zurek scaling predictions and signatures of the Kosterlitz–Thouless phase transition.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 638, P: 79-85
item.author: T. I. Andersen, N. Astrakhantsev, X. Mi

item.title: Quantum coarsening and collective dynamics on a programmable simulator
item.description:
A programmable quantum simulator based on Rydberg atom arrays is used to study the collective dynamics of a quantum phase transition and observe the phenomenon of quantum coarsening.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 638, P: 86-92
item.author: Tom Manovitz, Sophie H. Li, Mikhail D. Lukin

item.title: Stirring the false vacuum via interacting quantized bubbles on a 5,564-qubit quantum annealer
item.description:
Bubble formation is a signal of false vacuum decay, in which a system transitions from a local energy minimum to a true vacuum. Now, simulations on a quantum annealer show how interactions between bubbles drive the long-time dynamics of this process.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 21, P: 386-392
item.author: Jaka Vodeb, Jean-Yves Desaules, Zlatko Papić

item.title: A simulation of false vacuum decay using a quantum annealer
item.description:
False vacuum decay is a process of fundamental importance in quantum field theory. Here, a 5,564-qubit quantum annealer is used to simulate the dynamics of false vacuum decay and observe the formation of bubbles of true vacuum. This approach could provide insight into the role of phase transitions in the early Universe.
Type: News & Views Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 21, P: 351-352
item.author: Unknown Author

item.title: Gauge theories on a quantum computer
item.description:
Many important models in theoretical physics — including the standard model of particle physics — are governed by local ‘gauge’ symmetries. Now, a quantum computer has successfully simulated a lattice gauge theory by leveraging this rich symmetry structure.
Type: News & Views Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 21, P: 189-190
item.author: Karel Van Acoleyen

item.title: Programmable simulations of molecules and materials with reconfigurable quantum processors
item.description:
Quantum simulations of chemistry and materials are challenging due to the complexity of correlated systems. A framework based on reconfigurable qubit architectures and digital–analogue simulations provides a hardware-efficient path forwards.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 21, P: 289-297
item.author: Nishad Maskara, Stefan Ostermann, Susanne F. Yelin

item.title: Where analogue and digital meet
item.description:
Realizing a useful quantum advantage on noisy intermediate-scale quantum hardware is challenging. A proposal now suggests a hybrid digital–analogue hardware-efficient approach for reconfigurable qubit platforms to simulate strongly interacting matter.
Type: News & Views Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 21, P: 185-186
item.author: Kai-Niklas Schymik

item.title: Scaling and networking a modular photonic quantum computer
item.description:
A proof-of-principle study reports a complete photonic quantum computer architecture that can, once appropriate component performance is achieved, deliver a universal and fault-tolerant quantum computer.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 638, P: 912-919
item.author: H. Aghaee Rad, T. Ainsworth, Y. Zhang

item.title: Observation of a finite-energy phase transition in a one-dimensional quantum simulator
item.description:
Long-range interactions have been predicted to enable a phase transition in one-dimensional systems. An experiment now validates this hypothesis in a trapped-ion quantum simulator by observing a finite-energy phase transition in one dimension.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 21, P: 374-379
item.author: Alexander Schuckert, Or Katz, Christopher Monroe

item.title: Tabletop wonders
item.description:
To kick off the International Year of Quantum Science and Technology, we highlight recent progress in the use of quantum simulators to tackle problems in high-energy physics and cosmology.
Type: Editorial Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 21, P: 1
item.author: Unknown Author

item.title: Cold-atom quantum simulators of gauge theories
item.description:
Large-scale quantum simulations of gauge theories are relevant to high-energy and condensed matter physics. This Review covers recent developments in simulating lattice gauge theories using cold atoms.
Type: Reviews Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 21, P: 25-36
item.author: Jad C. Halimeh, Monika Aidelsburger, Bing Yang

item.title: Long-lived entanglement of molecules in magic-wavelength optical tweezers
item.description:
By engineering an exceptionally controlled environment using rotationally magic optical tweezers, long-lived entanglement between pairs of molecules using detectable hertz-scale interactions can be achieved.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 637, P: 827-832
item.author: Daniel K. Ruttley, Tom R. Hepworth, Simon L. Cornish

item.title: Confinement in a \({{\mathbb{Z}}}_{2}\) lattice gauge theory on a quantum computer
item.description:
Gauge theories host important phenomena such as confinement that are difficult to study theoretically. Advances in quantum computers have now made it possible to perform digital quantum simulations of confinement dynamics in a gauge theory.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 21, P: 312-317
item.author: Julius Mildenberger, Wojciech Mruczkiewicz, Philipp Hauke

item.title: Formation of individual stripes in a mixed-dimensional cold-atom Fermi–Hubbard system
item.description:
Observations of the formation of individual stripes in a mixed-dimensional cold-atom Fermi–Hubbard quantum simulator are described, enhancing understanding of the phase diagram of high-temperature superconducting materials and the relationship between charge pairs and stripes.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 637, P: 57-62
item.author: Dominik Bourgund, Thomas Chalopin, Timon A. Hilker

item.title: Observation of microscopic confinement dynamics by a tunable topological θ-angle
item.description:
Topological terms arise naturally in gauge theories but have been difficult to implement in quantum simulators. Now, a tunable topological θ-angle is demonstrated with a cold-atom platform.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 21, P: 155-160
item.author: Wei-Yong Zhang, Ying Liu, Jian-Wei Pan

item.title: Time-domain oscillations between distant spin qubits coupled via virtual photons
item.description:
In a device comprising two double quantum dots separated by a 250-μm-long superconducting resonator, virtual photons in the resonator are shown to mediate the coupling of electron spins between the quantum dots. When the spin–spin coupling is activated for a controlled duration, oscillations between the spins are observed.
Type: News & Views Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 21, P: 23-24
item.author: Unknown Author

item.title: Cavity-mediated iSWAP oscillations between distant spins
item.description:
Coupling semiconductor spin qubits over long distances using a superconducting resonator makes different quantum architectures possible. Now, the coherent swapping of quantum states has been observed between qubits coupled using this design.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 21, P: 168-174
item.author: Jurgen Dijkema, Xiao Xue, Lieven M. K. Vandersypen

item.title: Quantum error correction below the surface code threshold
item.description:
Two below-threshold surface code memories on superconducting processors markedly reduce logical error rates, achieving high efficiency and real-time decoding, indicating potential for practical large-scale fault-tolerant quantum algorithms.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 638, P: 920-926
item.author: Rajeev Acharya, Dmitry A. Abanin, Nicholas Zobrist

item.title: Learning high-accuracy error decoding for quantum processors
item.description:
A recurrent, transformer-based neural network, called AlphaQubit, learns high-accuracy error decoding to suppress the errors that occur in quantum systems, opening the prospect of using neural-network decoders for real quantum hardware.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 635, P: 834-840
item.author: Johannes Bausch, Andrew W. Senior, Pushmeet Kohli

item.title: Universal dynamics exposed by interaction quenches
item.description:
No Description
Type: News & Views Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 20, P: 1855-1856
item.author: Chandrasekhar Ramanathan

item.title: Entanglement and iSWAP gate between molecular qubits
item.description:
Intrinsic molecular resources are used to implement a two-qubit iSWAP gate using individually trapped X1Σ+ NaCs molecules.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 637, P: 821-826
item.author: Lewis R. B. Picard, Annie J. Park, Kang-Kuen Ni

item.title: Superconducting circuits feel the pull of synthetic magnetism
item.description:
Superconducting qubits can be fabricated and controlled in large numbers, which makes them an appealing platform for quantum simulations of many-body physics. However, a scalable way of implementing electromagnetism has been lacking — until now.
Type: News & Views Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 20, P: 1859-1860
item.author: Alicia J. Kollár

item.title: A synthetic magnetic vector potential in a 2D superconducting qubit array
item.description:
Arrays of superconducting transmon qubits can be used to study the Bose–Hubbard model. Synthetic electromagnetic fields have now been added to this analogue quantum simulation platform.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 20, P: 1881-1887
item.author: Ilan T. Rosen, Sarah Muschinske, William D. Oliver

item.title: Fast quantum gas formation via electromagnetically induced transparency cooling
item.description:
Current methods for directly cooling atomic gases to quantum degeneracy involve time-consuming steps. A method based on electromagnetically induced transparency now achieves quantum degeneracy with a notable reduction in preparation time.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 21, P: 63-69
item.author: Mingjie Xin, Wui Seng Leong, Shau-Yu Lan

item.title: Non-Abelian chiral dynamics in a lattice under synthetic SU(2) gauge fields
item.description:
A tunable SU(2) gauge field has been realized experimentally in a Raman momentum lattice using ultracold atoms. The chiral dynamics of the system have been investigated under different gauge potentials, whose non-Abelian nature was confirmed through observation of the non-Abelian Aharonov–Bohm effect.
Type: News & Views Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 20, P: 1710-1711
item.author: Unknown Author

item.title: Two-axis twisting using Floquet-engineered XYZ spin models with polar molecules
item.description:
A study demonstrates the application of Floquet Hamiltonian engineering to ultracold trapped polar molecules to realize interactions relevant to quantum metrology and many-body physics.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 633, P: 332-337
item.author: Calder Miller, Annette N. Carroll, Jun Ye

item.title: Bose–Einstein condensation of light in a semiconductor quantum well microcavity
item.description:
Photon Bose–Einstein condensation is observed in a semiconductor laser, where thermalization and condensation of photons occur using an InGaAs quantum well and an open microcavity. The distinction between regimes of photon Bose–Einstein condensation and conventional lasing are clearly identified.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Photonics Details: Volume: 18, P: 1083-1089
item.author: Ross C. Schofield, Ming Fu, Rupert F. Oulton

item.title: Precise control and non-destructive readout of quantum states of ion motion
item.description:
A quantum control technique is used to directly couple trapped-ion motional modes with high fidelity, enabling non-destructive measurements of the quantum harmonic oscillator states of atomic motion. The strong coupling rate and precise manipulation of the quantum states achieved with this technique could lead to advances in quantum information processing.
Type: News & Views Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 20, P: 1544-1545
item.author: Unknown Author

item.title: Scalable spin squeezing from finite-temperature easy-plane magnetism
item.description:
Generating highly squeezed states for quantum sensing requires precise entanglement properties, which makes it a hard task. Now a conjecture identifies a realistic regime of magnetic order at finite temperatures that enables scalable spin squeezing.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 20, P: 1575-1581
item.author: Maxwell Block, Bingtian Ye, Norman Y. Yao

item.title: Anyons go universal
item.description:
Topological quantum computers are predicted to perform calculations by manipulating quasiparticles known as non-Abelian anyons. A type of non-Abelian anyon that supports universal quantum gates has now been simulated using superconducting qubits.
Type: News & Views Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 20, P: 1373-1374
item.author: Trond I. Andersen, Xiao Mi

item.title: Antiferromagnetic phase transition in a 3D fermionic Hubbard model
item.description:
Antiferromagnetic phase transition is observed in a three-dimensional fermionic Hubbard system comprising lithium-6 atoms in a uniform optical lattice with approximately 800,000 sites.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 632, P: 267-272
item.author: Hou-Ji Shao, Yu-Xuan Wang, Jian-Wei Pan

item.title: Ultracold molecules that interact from afar form elusive quantum state
item.description:
A gas of molecules that interact over long distances has been cooled to mere nanokelvins, resulting in the emergence of a state known as a Bose–Einstein condensate — the first of its kind in this type of molecular system.
Type: News & Views Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 631, P: 283-284
item.author: Lauriane Chomaz

item.title: Observation of the scaling dimension of fractional quantum Hall anyons
item.description:
The scaling dimension of fractional quantum Hall anyons shows agreement with expectations following examination of thermal-to-shot-noise crossover measurements by fitting to the predicted finite-temperature expression involving both the scaling dimension of quasiparticles and their charge.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 632, P: 517-521
item.author: A. Veillon, C. Piquard, F. Pierre

item.title: Non-Abelian braiding of Fibonacci anyons with a superconducting processor
item.description:
Superconducting qubits have been used to realize a quantum many-body state that is capable of universal topological quantum computation.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 20, P: 1469-1475
item.author: Shibo Xu, Zheng-Zhi Sun, Dong-Ling Deng

item.title: Topological edge and corner states in bismuth fractal nanostructures
item.description:
The interplay between topology and fractals in real materials has remained challenging to study. Now, topological states are demonstrated in fractional-dimensional Sierpinski triangles made from bismuth.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 20, P: 1421-1428
item.author: R. Canyellas, Chen Liu, C. Morais Smith

item.title: Quantum squeezing in a nonlinear mechanical oscillator
item.description:
Mechanical modes promise applications in continuous-variable quantum information processing, but only if the final two elements—squeezing and nonlinearity—are achieved. Experiments with an oscillator coupled to a transmon qubit now achieve this.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 20, P: 1448-1453
item.author: Stefano Marti, Uwe von Lüpke, Matteo Fadel

item.title: How do fish know where a sound comes from? Scientists have an answer
item.description:
A dual hearing system helps fish pinpoint a sound’s source — plus uncovering the secrets of the sensory structures that respond to touch during sex.
Type: News Journal: Nature Details: No Volume/Page Info
item.author: Nick Petrić Howe, Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Experimental quantum computational chemistry with optimized unitary coupled cluster ansatz
item.description:
The application of quantum computing to computational chemistry faces various experimental and theoretical challenges. Now, a quantum simulation on a noisy quantum device has achieved chemical accuracy for small H2 and LiH molecules.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 20, P: 1240-1246
item.author: Shaojun Guo, Jinzhao Sun, Jian-Wei Pan

item.title: Coherence limits in lattice atom interferometry at the one-minute scale
item.description:
Applications of atom interferometry require sufficiently long coherence times. Now, confining atoms in an optical lattice shows that the decoherence rate slows down markedly at hold times that exceed tens of seconds.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Physics Details: Volume: 20, P: 1234-1239
item.author: Cristian D. Panda, Matthew Tao, Holger Müller

item.title: Twitter suspended 70,000 accounts after the Capitol riots and it curbed misinformation
item.description:
Removal of users shows the role social media companies could play in preventing misinformation sharing — plus how physicists coaxed ultracold molecules into an exotic quantum state.
Type: News Journal: Nature Details: No Volume/Page Info
item.author: Benjamin Thompson, Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Observation of Bose–Einstein condensation of dipolar molecules
item.description:
Bose–Einstein condensate of sodium–caesium molecules is observed by means of evaporative cooling and collisional shielding.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 631, P: 289-293
item.author: Niccolò Bigagli, Weijun Yuan, Sebastian Will

item.title: A site-resolved two-dimensional quantum simulator with hundreds of trapped ions
item.description:
In this work, stable trapping of a two-dimensional Wigner crystal of above 500 ions is achieved, and the quantum simulation of 300 ions with individual state detection demonstrated.
Type: Research Journal: Nature Details: Volume: 630, P: 613-618
item.author: S.-A. Guo, Y.-K. Wu, L.-M. Duan
